intro: Phlox carolina var. puberula, commonly known as the Downy Meadow Phlox, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Polemoniaceae family and is characterized by its showy, clustered flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodlands, and it thrives in partial to full sun. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered with a fine layer of downy hair, giving it a soft, textured appearance. The flowers are usually pink to purple in color, adding vibrant color to the landscape during its blooming season.
